author: Michael Muncaster
title: Leaving the EU could put 1,200 jobs at risk, warns Northumberland County Council leader
text:
Leaving the EU could put 1,200 jobs at risk, warns Northumberland County Council leader 15:30, 28 May 2016 Council leader Grant Davey fears the jobs could go if Northumberland County Council loses up to £28m of EU funding Shares Get daily news by email Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire The Union Jack flies behind the European Union flag 
Politicians in Northumberland have been bitterly divided over the risk to the county’s economy posed by Brexit. 
Research by the Northumberland Labour group claims up to 1,200 jobs could go if Northumberland County Council lost up to £28m of EU funding. 
And the group fears more than £4m a year would be lost from the county’s economy if the jobs were cut. 
But pro-Brexit MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan has dismissed the findings, claiming leaving the EU would help the council to flourish. 
Councillor Grant Davey, leader of Northumberland County Council, said: “We are very concerned that a vote for Brexit would be devastating to the Northumberland economy. 
“We are already dealing with more than 80% of cuts to council funding and we may have to deal with further extreme shocks to the economy through a Brexit vote. 
Councillor Grant Davey 
“Lets be clear, there are hundreds of jobs within the council and its partners which rely on European funding. 
“Nobody from the Brexit campaign has answered the simple question – what happens to real people, the real economy and real communities if they get their way and leave the EU?” 
Mrs Trevelyan, who represents Berwick and is part of the Vote Leave campaign, hit back claiming jobs would be put at risk if Britain stayed in the EU. 
She said: “All funds received by councils, including Northumberland County Council, is UK taxpayers’ money sent via the EU, some of which is given back to us with strict conditions. 
“If we vote to leave the EU, we can spend £350m per week on our own priorities, which will include ensuring councils are properly funded. 
“It will also enable us to spend more money on our NHS, public services, and be able to invest more in science and technology.” 
Conservative MP for Berwick Anne-Marie Trevelyan 
The Labour group fears the farming industry would be the hardest hit if Britain left the EU, and workers could lose up to 50% of their income. 
Coun Davey said: “Brexit campaigners need to tell us if their plans will give a cast iron guarantee on upland farming incomes, business investment and job creation and public sector funding, which is reliant on EU funding. They are proposing a ‘leap into the dark’ which will have a real impact on families and individuals across Northumberland.” 
But Mrs Trevelyan believes Britain’s farms would thrive outside of the EU. 
She said: “The system does not work for our farmers. 
“We can create a better one designed with them in mind, and stop sending our money to French farmers at the expense of our own.”
